isis.stitle: HEAT VENTILATION AIR CONDITIONING (HVAC), Thermostatic Expansion Valve (TXV) System, March 2007 and Later - SERVICE PROCEDURES FOR R-134a - DISCHARGING THE SYSTEM (REFRIGERANT RECOVERY)

warning.para:
Before doing any of the work below, read the SERVICE WARNINGS
. Failure to read the Service Warnings and to be aware of the dangers involved when working with refrigerant could lead to serious personal injury.

note.para: Although your service equipment may appear physically different from the equipment shown here, the function of the equipment used to perform each service procedure is basically the same. If you are performing these service procedures using service equipment different from that shown, refer to the manufacturer's instructions supplied with that equipment.
If the system is being discharged because a leak is suspected, the leak must be located before discharging the system. Refer to LEAK DETECTION .

step1.para: Empty the 'recovered oil' catch bottle on the recovery station. This is necessary to determine the amount of oil recovered during the refrigerant recovery procedure.
Remove the protection caps from both service ports.

On the recovery station and hose fittings, verify that all valves are closed. The valves at the recovery station must be set to the CLOSED position. The valves at the quick-disconnect fittings must be set fully counter-clockwise (CCW).

figure.caption: Figure 41. Typical Equipment Hookup for Servicing the System

step1.para: Connect the recovery station to the system as follows:

step2.para: Start with the blue low pressure hose, and connect it to the low pressure service port located on the evaporator outlet line.
Connect the red hose to the high pressure service port located on the compressor-to-condenser line.

step1.para: Open (turn cw) the valves on the quick-disconnect fittings connected to the service ports on the vehicle.
Set both hand valves on the recovery station to the RECOVERY/VACUUM position.

note.para: During the recovery process in the next step, refrigerant may become trapped in the filter-drier. Heating the filter-drier with a heat gun will force the refrigerant out of the filter-drier and assure that all of the refrigerant is recovered from the system.

warning.para: Never use an open flame torch to heat the filter-drier. Heating the filter-drier with an open flame could result in equipment damage and/or bodily injury.

step1.para: Turn the recovery station main power switch on and press the RECOVER button. The recovery station will automatically shut off when the refrigerant in the system has been exhausted to the storage tank.
Close the valves on the quick-disconnect fittings by turning them fully CCW; and set both valves on the recovery station to the CLOSED position.

When recovering refrigerant by use of a recovery station, system oil is separated from the refrigerant during the recovery cycle. When the refrigerant recovery operation is complete, the recovery station will drain the oil into the station's calibrated catch bottle. The amount of oil recovered may be used to determine the amount of NEW oil that must be added back to the A/C system. Refer to OIL FILL GUIDELINES, .
Disconnect the blue and red hoses from the service ports on the vehicle.
Work may now begin on the air conditioning system.
